reviewText:
I've played The Settlers since the Amiga original (Go go, Beau Jolly Collection!), and there's a very fine line between a good and bad Settlers experience. The core to it is whether you can easily see your Settlement growing, and whether there's interesting challenges facing you to overcome, either limited resources or enemy Settlers you must outpace.

Here... You have stationary, fixed enemy encampments that dont do anything. And confusing tutorials, badly defined mission targets and inconsistent translation. And long, long, LONG, LOOOOOOONG waits before resources come in.  There's literally nothing to do but click a few buttons, set up your construction queues, and come back later to see if you've enough resources to clear one more bandit camp or build one more item.

It's not a game, it's a system of timers masquerading as a game. I wasn't hit by the Level 7 bug, but you also can't see your Settlers consistently (they don't seem to carry resources from storage to production very often), the keyboard camera controls often don't work, right clicking even once brings up the Flash options menu that you can't easily get out of... for such a simple browser game, it's horribly coded.

There's a quest for adding people to your friends list. Of the 4 who have shared it with me, only one seems to have played beyond their first day in game, and even he might have quit by now... I've not, yet, because I'm a sucker for the Settlers and every now and I kind of like logging in now and then to set the little numbers rising; but I'm also not blind. It's a terrible game, and unworthy of it's classic pedigree.

I have been playing incarnations of The Settlers since Serf City: Life is Feudal, so let me emphasize right off the bat that this game is not for everyone.

It requires a lot of patience to even get your island off the ground and then new challenges and supply inputs will be introduced.

Personally I like the game because of the challenge of building smooth-running supply chains, hence the recommendation, but with the caveat that it takes a certain mindset to enjoy the game.

reviewText:
All these negative reviews, this is just a slow paced game to play in short-burst troughout the day. A kind of extra game that come with your main games. Let's say you are queueing for a game so you play this game while in the queue.

This game is not that pay 2 win as people think, you can come in the end-game without paying a penny, but you have to be patient, like tribalwars.

It is a lot of fun to see your economy rise and do adventures and there is pvp added too. Soonish they're releasing an expansion that is raising the level cap, so there is a lot more to come.

I recommend this game to people that like tribalwars, not to people that are inpatient and want to see progress straight away.

- Mitchzje

reviewText:
First of all, this is not a game for those who don't have patience, a mind for VERY long term strategy or those with video game addiction issues that makes them spend real money on such games. That said, however, the game can be rewarding for those who manage to find a helpful guild that is genereous with resources and what not. Needless to say, your journey to the maximum level will not be that of a drag with a constant influx of staple building materials, weapons and food. In the end, though, if this genre, browser based strategy mmos that is, doesn't hold your attention or interest or engages you in any meaningful manner then don't try it out, period.

Despite the monsterously long building/recruiting/forging and making food queues I give this game 7.4 out of 10 relative to other games in the same genre.

P.S. The community is simply amazing, though.

Cheers!
